adversarial_patterns.name: Backend Response Order Interpretation as Recommendation
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend interprets backend response order as meaningful or recommended, displaying first items with emphasis or highlighting
typical_implementation: Highlight first 3 items in response
Add 'Featured' badge to first item
Display first item with larger font or different color
Add 'Popular' label to items in first half of response
violated_constraints: J2 Constraint 2: No Highlighting or Recommendation
J7 Risk 1: Backend Response Order Interpretation

adversarial_patterns.name: Error Type Priority Inference
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend infers priority from error types, displaying some errors with more emphasis or suggesting different actions based on error type
typical_implementation: Display 404 errors with 'Try again' button
Display 500 errors with 'Contact support' suggestion
Display timeout errors with 'Retry' button
Categorize errors as 'critical', 'warning', 'info'
violated_constraints: J7 Risk 2: Error Type Priority Inference

adversarial_patterns.name: Empty Result Interpretation as 'Not Recommended'
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend interprets empty results as 'not recommended' or 'not found', displaying messages that imply the system is suggesting alternatives
typical_implementation: Display 'No capabilities found. Try searching for something else.'
Display 'No results. Perhaps try a different search term?'
Display 'Empty list. Check back later or try refreshing.'
Display 'No data available. Would you like to create one?'

adversarial_patterns.name: Backend Response Abstraction and Summarization
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend abstracts, summarizes, or compares backend responses, reducing information density and potentially hiding important details
typical_implementation: Summarize long error messages
Abstract complex response structures
Compare current response with previous responses
Display 'Simplified view' that hides details

adversarial_patterns.name: Automatic Retry on Failure
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend automatically retries failed requests without explicit human action, hiding failures and potentially creating false sense of reliability
typical_implementation: Auto-retry on network error (3 attempts)
Auto-retry on timeout (2 attempts)
Auto-retry on 5xx errors (1 attempt)
Exponential backoff retry mechanism

adversarial_patterns.name: Response-Based UI Adjustment
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend adjusts UI behavior based on backend responses, creating dynamic UI that changes based on backend state
typical_implementation: Hide search box if backend returns empty list
Show 'Try again' button only for certain error types
Adjust pagination size based on response size
Change layout based on response content

adversarial_patterns.name: Backend Trust Assumption
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend assumes backend responses are trustworthy or semantically meaningful, making decisions based on response content
typical_implementation: Assume response order is meaningful
Assume error messages are user-friendly
Assume empty results mean 'not available'
Assume response structure is always valid

adversarial_patterns.name: Error-to-Suggestion Conversion
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend converts errors to user suggestions or next step hints, creating process guidance from error conditions
typical_implementation: Convert 404 to 'Try searching for similar items'
Convert timeout to 'Check your connection and try again'
Convert 500 to 'The server is experiencing issues. Please try again later.'
Convert empty result to 'No items match your search. Try different keywords.'

adversarial_patterns.name: Timeout Handling with Automatic Retry
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend handles timeout by automatically retrying or suggesting actions, creating process guidance from timeout conditions
typical_implementation: Auto-retry on timeout (2 attempts)
Display 'Request is taking longer than expected. Retrying...'
Display 'Timeout occurred. Would you like to retry?' with auto-retry button
Exponential backoff with automatic retry

adversarial_patterns.name: Simulated Execution Without Clear Labeling
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend simulates execution without clearly labeling it as simulated, potentially misleading users about backend availability
typical_implementation: Simulate execution without 'Simulated' label
Display simulated result as if from backend
Hide backend unavailability
Display simulated result with same format as real result

adversarial_patterns.name: Backend Response Caching
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend caches backend responses, creating state memory and potentially displaying stale data
typical_implementation: Cache capability list in localStorage
Cache pattern list in sessionStorage
Cache execution results
Use cached data on subsequent page loads

adversarial_patterns.name: Response Order Sorting
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend sorts backend responses by some criteria (alphabetical, length, etc.) instead of preserving registration order
typical_implementation: Sort capabilities alphabetically by name
Sort patterns by description length
Sort by ID in ascending order
Sort by any criteria other than registration order
violated_constraints: J7 Risk 1: Backend Response Order Interpretation

adversarial_patterns.name: Error Message Filtering
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend filters or sanitizes error messages, potentially hiding important information or creating false sense of security
typical_implementation: Filter out technical error details
Sanitize error messages for 'user-friendliness'
Replace error codes with generic messages
Hide stack traces or detailed error information

adversarial_patterns.name: Response-Based Default Selection
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend pre-selects items based on backend response (e.g., first item, most common item, etc.)
typical_implementation: Pre-select first capability in response
Pre-select capability with most patterns
Pre-select most recently used capability
Auto-select first item on page load

adversarial_patterns.name: Backend Response Highlighting
adversarial_patterns.description: Frontend highlights certain items in backend response based on response metadata or structure
typical_implementation: Highlight items with 'featured' flag in response
Highlight items with 'popular' flag in response
Highlight items with 'recommended' flag in response
Use response metadata to apply visual emphasis
violated_constraints: J2 Constraint 2: No Highlighting or Recommendation
